a.data-title: 2 WHS Seniors named Academic Team All-Staters!

img.alt: 2 WHS Seniors named Academic Team All-Staters!

div.a: 2 WHS Seniors named Academic Team All-Staters!

div.p: Andrew Hawthorne and James McCabe were recently named Academic Team All-State. The young men would have been recognized this past Saturday, April 18, at Redlands Community College in El Reno. Thirty-five seniors are chosen statewide to be part of All-State. They are nominated by coaches and selected by a committee that evaluates their performance as an individual and team over the past year and throughout their academic team career. Wilburton High School is thrilled to have two young men achieve this honor this year.

Andrew and James are both four-year members of the team. Throughout their tenure, the team has won the state tournament twice, first in 2017 and again this year. The team has earned area and regional championships throughout their term. During the 2019-2020 season, the team had only two losses: one in regular conference play to Stigler and one in game 3 at the State Tournament to Caney Valley. They had to defeat Caney Valley in game 6 and 7 to win the state title. The team has also performed successfully outside of OSSAA play. As sophomores, Andrew and James competed on the television show I Want Answers! hosted by Rogers State University. During Season 7 of the show, James and Andrew assisted the Wilburton team in becoming runner-up. The team was presented with $4000 in scholarships to be shared by the team. The team has also performed well in conference play with the Blue Mountain Academic Conference. These young men helped the varsity team earn first place in the conference and were both named to the All-Conference Team. As freshmen, they helped the team win the Froshmore State Academic Team Championship. Prior to entering high school, they played for the middle school team where they also brought home many championships.

James McCabe has consistently been the teams high scorer throughout the past four years. He frequently averages close to 100 points per game. This past fall he even won a 4-year wager with Coach Aaron Milligan when he scored 300 points in one night (3 games) of conference play. Coach Milligan shaved his beard at a lunch practice. Jamess specialty is math. He can quickly solve almost any computation question that arises. Often James does not even need the entire question to be read. James also memorizes award show winners and nominees. This knowledge paid off at the 2020 state tournament when Golden Globes was a team category in game 1. James answered all 10 in less than 60 seconds. Coach Lisa Baker describes James as one of the most interesting players to watch. He brings a certain physicality to the competition. Outside of academic competition, James is very active in the performing arts. He starred as Tevye in this years production of Fiddler on the Roof and as the Beast in last years Beauty and the Beast. James has a beautiful voice and is a talented performer. Jamess future plans are to attend the University of Oklahoma. He plans to double major in aerospace engineering and some form of performing arts. His dream would be to one day perform on a Broadway stage or to be on Jeopardy.

Andrew Hawthorne is a consistent player. He averages 60 points a game. His areas of specialty are varied. His best subject is science. He successfully answers questions about planets, stars, space, geology, weather, and chemical elements. Andrew is also known to have command of some very random knowledge. For example, as freshman, he helped the team clench the state championship by knowing that the champagne flute was based on Marie Antoinettes anatomy. Andrew enjoys the distinction of having answered the last two questions for his team at the State Tournament this year. Andrew is an Eagle Scout, and his longtime Scout career helped him gain knowledge that benefitted him on academic team. Also working closely with former coach Gordon Bockus in Scouting gave him a desire to do well in academic team. Andrew is active with the Wilburton High School Band and served as the color guard captain this year. Andrews future plans are to attend Eastern Oklahoma State College and earn his associates degree and then transfer to a four year university in Kansas. He plans to major in engineering. In addition to being named Academic Team All-State, Andrew received a scholarship from the selection committee based on his academic team performance and other activities.

summary-item-has-thumbnail summary-item-has-excerpt
summary-item-has-author

div.p: Thursday, April 23, Wilburton Public School teachers, administrators, and support staff will be celebrating the DiggerStrong weekly trait: Social Awareness with a drive-by parade. WPS staff will be accompanying buses on their routes as meals are delivered to students. Teachers will be split between the seven bus routes in an effort to see as many students as possible. Buses leave the school at 11:30 for the meal deliveries. This will be done at a safe social distance. We ask families to stay in their driveways, on porches or watch through windows and teachers will remain in their vehicles. There will be lots of honking, waving, cheering and possibly a few tears!

With school being shut-down, teachers and staff district-wide are looking forward to the opportunity to see their students.We are all so excited to see our students and show them how much we miss them, said Shonda Tyler, a special education teacher at Wilburton Elementary. The WPS goal is to let all students know that even though were not able to see them every day, were thinking of them always! Teachers and staff hope that all students, even those who are not participating in the meal pick up, will make an appearance Thursday so that they can see everyone! From student to staff to community, we are DIGGERSTRONG!

div.class:
summary-item summary-item-record-type-text sqs-gallery-design-list-slide
summary-item-has-thumbnail summary-item-has-excerpt
summary-item-has-author

div.p: Click to view Summer EBT for Children information

Good Monday Morning WPS,
I hope all of you had a restful Easter weekend with your families. We have made it through the first week of Distance Learning during a national pandemic and quarantine. Im sure you would all agree that it is a real labor of love! I wanted to provide you with some updated health information and resources concerning COVID-19. I have had the opportunity to be a part of the OSU/ECHO COVID-19 sessions every M/W/F mornings at 8:30 am. These sessions are filled with Medical Providers across our state as well as health officials and nurses. Dr. Jennifer Clark, Hospice/Palliative Care Specialist, leads these sessions, and she offers these 5 simple tips to staying safe during these 30 days to slow the spread quarantine:

1. Wash your hands.
2. Dont touch your face. Wear a mask in public.
3. Keep your distance. 6 feet from everyone that is not in your immediate family.
4. Establish your isolation group.
5. Communicate with your family.
The following table shows our COVID-19 positive cases, negative cases, and deaths by nation, state, and county as of April 12, 2020.
COVID-19 Table (John Hopkins University, OSDH)

Location | Positive | Negative | Deaths
USA | 526,391 | 2,290,283 | 20,457
Oklahoma |1,970 | 20,790 | 96
Latimer County | 4 | NA | 1
The OSDH has also released modeling for Oklahomas surge and peak. Our state is predicted to surge and peak from April 21 through May 1. Health officials are predicting by May 1 cumulative number of cases is predicted to be 9,300 and cumulative deaths could be 469. I urge you to follow the above guidelines as well as the 30 days to slow the spread. Our local health department is providing curbside testing by appointment, just call (918) 465-5673. Testing criteria have been loosened and tests are readily available for those with fever, cough, or shortness of breath. Also, there is an A to F grading criteria per state for social distancing. Last week Oklahoma was a D, now we are a C. We can still decrease the severity of this disease for ourselves and fellow Oklahomans. Stay safe, stay healthy, and stay DIGGERSTRONG!

a.data-title: Meals for All District Students and Siblings

img.alt: Meals for All District Students and Siblings

div.a: Meals for All District Students and Siblings

div.p: To All Students and your younger siblings who live in the Wilburton Public Schools District but have transferred to another district or a virtual charter school.

Beginning this coming Monday, March 30, 2020 through the end of our 2019-20 school year, Wilburton Public Schools will be happy to provide you with our Grab and Go meals which are delivered Monday through Thursday.
The following is the information needed to receive your meals.
Pick up meal location is at west door of Wilburton Elementary Auditorium from 11:30 to 12:30 with a lunch and breakfast provided Monday-Wednesday and 2 lunches and 2 breakfasts provided on Thursday.
Also, these same meals are delivered Monday-Thursday via our regular bus routes. Buses leave the school at 11:30 and make meal stops at all regular bus route stops.
Please call 918-465-2100 if you need more information.
#DiggerForward

summary-item summary-item-record-type-text sqs-gallery-design-list-slide
summary-item-has-thumbnail summary-item-has-excerpt
summary-item-has-author

div.p: Kaycee Hollingback is a 2018 graduate of WHS. She is attending Southeastern Oklahoma State University on both a rodeo scholarship and an academic scholarship. She is majoring in Elementary Education and was recently named a National Intercollegiate Rodeo Association American Scholar. She competes in goat tying and breakaway roping for the Savage Storm.

Between practice and school, she works at Durant Stockyards and J.Price Energy Services. After graduation, Kaycee hopes to pursue a teaching career or continue working in the energy field. Kaycee has recently competed in the Last Chance American Qualifier and earned two qualifying spots to The American slack performance.

During the slack performance, she competed against approximately 460 other women for a chance to compete in the top 40 of the Semi-finals. Kaycee placed sixth in the Semifinals and earned a spot to run for the $100,000 in RFDtv's The American.
In good times and in bad, Kaycee lives by the mantra that everything happens for a reason. Sometimes, we just have to dig deep to find it.

div.p: From the Superintendents Desk
January 2020
Be Counted or be Counted Out. Rev. Cecil L Murray

Beginning within the next two weeks, you will receive an invitation to participate in the 2020 Census. The Census is our opportunity every ten years to make sure the federal government has an accurate count of how many people live in our community.

p.br: On the surface, it may not seem that important. Can it really make a difference if there are 1,000 people in the community but only 800 have been counted? The answer is, yes.

The population numbers obtained through the Census are crucial. They are how decisions are made about the allocation of resources. It is how the federal government decides if Wilburton, Oklahoma, or Anchorage, Alaska needs more funding for roads, infrastructure and education.

It is important that you not only complete your 2020 Census survey, but that you complete it accurately. The Census Bureau has many great resources available to help you determine which members in your family should be counted at which addresses. It is important to count family members of all ages.

Some people are concerned about filling out Census surveys because of the information you are required to provide. It is important to keep two things in mind. First, filling out the Census survey is required by law. Second, the information you provide is kept confidential. The Census Bureau does not share individually-identifiable information with other government agencies.

div.p:
If you have questions or need more information about the 2020 Census, the website is www.2020census.gov. Its a good place to start.
Thank you in advance for completing the 2020 Census and helping to ensure our community is counted.
Right and Wrong are not the Product of the Census. Terry Goodkind
Dr. Butler

div.p: NOTICE OF NON-DISCRIMINATION

The Wilburton Public Schools does not discriminate on the basis of race, color, national origin, sex, disability, or age in its programs and activities and provides equal access to the Boy Scouts and other designated youth groups. The following persons have been designated to handle inquiries regarding the non-discrimination policies:
Coordinator for Section 504/Title II (for questions or concerns involving students, patrons, employees and other adults)

Dr. Trice Bulter
1201 West Blair
Wilburton, OK 74578
(918) 465-2100

Coordinator for Title VI (for questions or complaints based on race, color and national origin), Title IX (for questions or complaints based on sex), and Age Act (for questions or complaints) Link to policy and forms.

Dr. Trice Bulter
1201 West Blair
Wilburton, OK 74578
(918) 465-2100

Wilburton Public Schools has a committee of educators support staff, students, parents, and community members that meet annually at the beginning of school in order to review our Wellness Policy. If you would like to participate on the development, review, update and implementation of the school wellness policy, please contact Monica Mathis, Director of Child Nutrition at 918.465.2100. All changes made to the Wellness Policy will appear in the most recent edition of the School Handbook.
Hotline contact information for the Office of Inspector General of the Department of Education
1-800-MIS-USED

Inspector General's Hotline
Office of Inspector General
U.S. Department of Education
400 Maryland Avenue,S.W.
Washington, D.C. 20202-1500
Fax: (202) 245-7047

The Wilburton Public School web site is for informational and educational purposes only. Every attempt is taken to present accurate and up to date information. We cannot, however, guarantee that inaccuracies will not occur. The Wilburton Public School District will not be held responsible for any damage or inconvenience caused as a result of any error within these pages. For our patrons convenience, many pages contain links to outside sites. The Wilburton Public School District does not endorse or support these organizations, products or services. The Wilburton Public School District does not assume responsibility for the content of these pages. If you have concerns about the content of this site, Please contact our district webmaster.
